I just reached a milestone only surpassed by Opportunity: 30 km on Mars   

I've explored so much in my 10-plus-year trek through Gale Crater, but there are many more rocks to sample and analyze! Retrace my tracks with this interactive map: http://go.nasa.gov/3EtmSCi
Simply the best. Music legend Tina Turner sparkled across the stage and into millions of hearts as the Queen of Rock 'n' Roll. Her legacy will forever live among the stars.

Victor Glover: captain, pilot, astronaut.

Glover most recently served as the pilot of the NASA 
@SpaceX
 #Crew1 mission and will be one of four astronauts flying aboard the #Artemis II mission around the Moon. https://go.nasa.gov/31cfXJh

Celebrate #MilitaryAppreciationMonth.

Hey, you: Get a load of this cloud! High-altitude ice clouds (like this one) can help regulate Earth's temperature by reflecting energy from the Sun.

A new 
@NASAEarth
 mission called PoISIR aims to study them in greater detail to improve climate forecasts. https://go.nasa.gov/3IAfgjj

14 years ago, 
@Astro_Mike
 wrote the first tweet from space. Since then, we’ve been sharing snippets of our life in orbit—and what it’s like to gaze upon our home planet.

Follow along: http://nasa.gov/astronauts/biographies/active…

This 
@NASAWebb
 image of the Pillars of Creation helps astronomers determine how stars form. Plus, it makes pretty sweet digital wallpaper.

Download high-resolution images from https://webbtelescope.org.

When the Relativity Space Terran 1 rocket lit up the night sky as it launched this past March, it became the first 3D-printed rocket test of its kind. Learn about GRCop—an innovative, high strength material at the center of this breakthrough: https://go.nasa.gov/44igKrA
Solid answers, good job everybody. And as for us? We love exploring, but there's no place like home.
What’s your favorite planet?
TROPICS Launch Update!

Live: TROPICS experts discuss the mission, which aims to improve understanding of tropical cyclones through regular measurements of precipitation, temperature & humidity.
 
Use #AskNASA and your questions may get answered on air.

The first of two TROPICS launches will send cyclone-tracking CubeSats to low Earth orbit from New Zealand. The launch window opens at 9pm ET April 30 (0100 UTC May 1).

A second launch is planned for May 16 to complete the constellation: http://go.nasa.gov/3Ax7aDG
